title: At what age did you learn to read? - Quora

response.answer_text: I suppose at the age of three. Maybe earlier? I can't remember the time I couldn't read. I can't remember learning the skill. I have always known how to read. I remember when I was four I made it possible for my kindergarten teachers to sneak out for a quick cigarette. They gave me books (that had the script I am using to write this post). I had to read to the others. It was easy and quick for me. I remember learning the Gothic script (Frakturschrift). I think it was in primary school or so. I did it to read the books and the magazines published in the 1920s. My grandmother told me two important things that still haunt me: Latin script (the one I am using now) is dangerous. It damages the eyes. Gothic script is not dangerous. It does not damage the eyes.There are really two S’s. Not one.My grandmother was more used to Gothic script. That’s the one she learned at school. Because of nostalgic reasons I read a few books in that script every year. I can actually remember learning it. Of course I used the learning by doing method. This means that occasionally I have to lower my head in shame in front of a freaky capital letter. My early reading skills caused some confusions. E.g. I could not understand why some people visited other people in the middle of the day and took their clothes off. Yes, they were in love, but love and being naked are two very different things. This is what happens if you read novels before you find out sex exists. The novels were not very explicit, but some details got me a bit confused. I also remember two souls that were united after a wedding. In their bedroom. In the middle of the night. Very strange witchcraft! I used to approach random aunties at parties and ask them about their male companions: “Is he your lover?” In my novels aristocrats were often married but that was irrelevant. Their lovers were very relevant. So basically I accused some nice people of adultery. Maybe I was right? My mother told me not to ask such questions. My objection: “But lovers are good people!” was not accepted. At that moment I understood that the life in the novels was somehow very different.

I learned to read when I was about 3 or 4 years old. My parents say that I was reading by then, but I could read so young I can’t even remember learning. Or that might just be because I’m super absentminded and have a not-so-great memory. I can barely remember any of my toddlerhood. I actually have a picture of baby-me holding a book (it was upside down, lol), but I could definitely NOT read at that age. I mean, you’d think that if I was able to read, I’d be out of diapers, too. I also had a high level of writing at an early age. Writing is something I enjoy, and I’ve always had a way with words, along with a good understanding of grammar, punctuation, etc. I think the reason my writing is so good, though, is because of extensive reading. Being exposed to a lot of books helped expand by vocabulary, and taught me techniques authors use in their writing. Nowadays, I read a ton of books well above my age level, and can go through them like wildfire. I’m also working on writing my own, although it’s just in the beginning stage. My love of reading started at an early age, and hasn’t stopped since.

OHHHHH! That’s a good one! I read Sally, Dick, and Jane in first grade!! I’m an old lady! We read in books called basalt because they were meant for that grade level. The teachers never noticed that I was learning disabled and having a hard time reading.I read at home somehow. I had lots of books and very educated parents. No one knew until 6th grade when I had to read in from of my class. I couldn't read it. My teacher talked to me and then my parents and my mother, who was a wonderful ex-teacher helped me by reading material with me.I managed to get through school with only her help. In college, I learned about learning disabilities and realized that I fit the category!!!!! I have two Master’s degrees which means I read a lot. It was never easy!!! When I read now, I read the story to myself and I was surprised to find out that other people don’t have to do that. The words just get “into their brains” without having to read to yourself. SOOOOO, you ask when did I learn to read? some people say that I still don’t because I have to read it to myself. GO figure!!!!

Around 6. When I was in my 40’s, someone told me that I couldn’t speak English before I went to school, and my Mum had to deliver me to kindergarten because I would run away (I remember the running away part). I remember my first book had pictures with the word below it, and I loved that book so much. I’m not sure if that book helped me read or learn English - or both. In grade one I got the hang of reading (and apparently English as well). Then I got in trouble for going ahead in the grade one reader and my Mum was summoned to the school. She told my Dad and he told me to get my coat - I was terrified that I was being sent away. Then we went to the store and I got The King of the Golden River by Ruskin, The Little Lame Prince by Mulock and two Bobbsey Twins books. After that, I would read anything that I came across, such as cereal boxes where I learned that Shreddies had butylated hydroxyanisole. My favorite presents have always been books and I would always get at least two Nancy Drews every year.

I can’t recall when I begun reading, only my earliest memory of reading. That was in infant school aged 4–5ish, and I remember it because I wasn’t being stimulated. We had quiet reading sessions where everyone had to go and get a book from the shelf in the hall, but there was an order that had to be followed. Dozens upon dozens of those dreary learn to read books. “This is Peter.” “Peter has a dog.” “The dog is called Fido.” I specifically remember asking the teacher if I could go for something more challenging but nein, “finish these first”. If I were a smart alec, I might have said something like “I don’t intend to live that long”. In reality, I just resigned myself to my fate. It’s fine, I was already reading proper big boy books at home anyway, with subordinate clauses ’n’ everything! I did eventually get recognised as a good reader though, and was promptly picked out to read a book to the class. My teacher, in an oral reading session, had discovered that I was a good reader. “Expressive” and “beautiful” were the adjectives routinely used during subsequent oral sessions throughout infant and primary school. Trouble was, sitting on a chair in front of the whole class, poised to read like a juvenile Roald Dahl at the start of a Tales of the Unexpected, left me shaking in my size threes. My expression got the hiccups, and I left feeling like Chamberlain facing the vote of no confidence. I did win the reading cup a little later, even got the Polaroid to prove it. They didn’t let you have any of the sweets that filled the cup though. It was all just for show. Stingy arses.

I don’t know. I know I could already read when I started school - I was five then. I know I could read when I got a set of the original A. A. Milne Winnie-the-Pooh stories for Christmas one year; my mother said that was the year I was four. I just remember clutching the new magically unfamiliar books and hiding under the table in the middle of my grandmother’s living room to read them. My mother started reading to me when I was six months old or thereabouts. I suspect I memorized the stories she read, then paged through the books by myself reciting the words, and somehow figured out that there was a connection between the black squiggles on the pages and words. After that, I could read, and I haven’t stopped since. Original question: What age did you learn how to read?

I think I was around 5 or 6, definitely before school. I would read books by Astrid Lindgren, a beloved writer in Estonia. Before learning how to read I would draw for hours, and after I learned to read, the same thing happened with books. I would read and read for hours, devouring nearly everything my mom had (for kids), as well as non-children’s fiction like The Hobbit. Eventually, when I went to school (in Estonia that’s when you’re seven) I read Harry Potter, the first four books in both Estonian and English, the rest only in English (the translation quality varies). So somewhere around 5 or 6. I think that’s a good age to learn how to read.

I could read when I was around the age of four. My mother was a former junior schoolteacher but she never gave any of us formal reading lessons. But she did read a great deal and I taught myself to read by following her book over her shoulder and asking what words sounded like and meant. And I followed that up by reading all the gossip in our local newspaper.

I want to say 3ish because I could recognize certain words. At 4 I could sound out words and by five I could read a children’s book on my own. I have an older brother who is 4 years older than I am and I would want to do what he was doing. I’m pretty sure that’s how I picked up the ability, by watching and listening my parents teach him how to sound out words.

My mum tells a story about my first day of school. I read a book to my Prep teacher and the class. She was apparently impressed/surprised and took me to the other classrooms in the school and had me read it to them too (it was a small country school). I was four & a half at the time so some time before that.

I started to learn how to read at around the age of three. I have a sister six years older, and she was always reading, so I wanted to copy her. I began to recognize written words that were repeated aloud. I was reading independently by kindergarten.
I don't actually remember NOT being able to read. I remember one or two books that must have been read to me. But I don't see it in my mind's eye. By the time I was 3 or 4 I read on my own.
4, with my nanny. at 5 I started school a year in advance
